g.text: observed in Hg1201 are close to the CDWtransition temperature
determined by resonant X-ray diffraction measurements
It has been shown that below this temperature, the Hall constant
levels off and the planar resistivity exhibits
CDW modulation is along [100]/[010], which is the same
direction as the bond nematicity in YBCO, but differs from the
diagonal nematicity in Hg1201. The fact that
implies that the CDW domain size
is much smaller than the sample dimensions, which results in the
different domains. This is consistent with the scattering experi-
ments, which revealed CDW correlations of a few nm
It should be stressed that the nature of the nematicity in Hg1201
differs from that in YBCO in several regards. First, in the case of
breaking of the electron system occurs in Hg1201 with a tetra-
gonal crystal symmetry. Second, the diagonal nematicity with
symmetry in Hg1201 is in stark contrast to the bond nematicity
symmetry in YBCO. Third, while the growth of the
diagonal nematicity is suppressed by the CDW formation in
Hg1201, no discernible anomaly is observed at
Our results shed light on the pseudogap physics. Nematicity in
the pseudogap phase is universal regardless of the number of
layers per primitive cell. Moreover, the diagonal nematicity
in Hg1201, observed in this study for the ﬁrst time, is associated
representation, in sharp contrast to the CDW order
nematicity is not a precursor of the CDW. Notice that in other
cuprates such as YBCO and Bi
CDW develop along the same bond direction and the precursor
The super-linear temperature behaviour of the nematicity in
YBCO and Hg1201 suggests that the pseudogap transition may
not belong to the two- or three-dimensional Ising universality
class. One possible explanation is that the nematicity may not be
a primary order parameter, whereas another possibility is that
pseudogap phenomena are associated with physics beyond the
Next, we discuss possible explanations of the diagonal nema-
ticity. Our results suggest that the diagonal nematicity is unlikely
due to a Pomeranchuk instability of the Fermi surface, which
prefers symmetry breaking along the bond direction
that we cannot rule out the possibility of complete rotational
symmetry may be consistent with the
. However, the interpretation of the polarised
in terms of loop-current-order is not unique,
and the observed magnetism appears to be dynamic rather than
truly static. In addition, it is an interesting open question whether
the loop-current order would explain the bond nematicity in
bilayer cuprates such as YBCO. Recent resistivity measurements
. Moreover, the direction of the nematicity
is not ﬁxed by the crystal axes, and depends on temperature and
hole concentration. At the present stage, the relationship between
this transport work and our thermodynamic result is an open
More scenarios have been suggested recently. One is based on
orbital for bond nematicity under the
, another is based on percolation of local
pseudogaps which may be consistent with nematic domain phe-
, and a third is based on phenomena beyond the
Landau paradigm, such as doped quantum spin liquid, which
may explain the superlinear onset intrinsically
retical and experimental investigations are highly desired to pin
down a mechanism of the diagonal nematicity.
. We have studied single crystals of Hg1201 grown by two different
≈ 0.11 and 0.125, small single crystals were grown by a solid-state
≈ 0.12, a small crystal was cut from a large crystal
annealing the crystal at high temperatures under oxygen atmosphere. The hole-
doping levels were determined from the superconducting transition temperature
dependence of the normalised magnetisation measured for
respectively. The crystals exhibit sharp superconducting transitions with
≈ 0.11, 0.12 and 0.125, respectively. The directions of the crys-
talline axes were determined by X-ray diffraction measurements.
. Magnetic torque was measured by the piezoresistive
. With a tiny amount of instant glue, tiny single
crystals of Hg1201 were carefully mounted onto the piezoresistive lever, which
forms an electrical bridge circuit with the neighbouring reference lever. Then, the

. For precise measurements of the in-plane magnetic torque, we use a system
consisting of a 2D vector magnet and a mechanical rotator (Supplementary Fig. 2),

on the rotation mechanism, which we use to determine the position of the sample
plane (Supplementary Fig. 2). The other is the

plane. The data are ﬁtted by a symmetric polynomial function, and
accordingly, we precisely determine the alignment of the

. To examine the presence of in-plane anisotropy
